verb.description: Lift or move to a higher position or level.
examples: she raised both arms above her head
his flag was raised over the city

verb.description: Increase the amount, level, or strength of.
examples: the aim was to raise awareness of the plight of the homeless

verb.description: Cause to occur or to be considered.
examples: the alarm was raised when he failed to return home
doubts have been raised about the future of the reprocessing plant

verb.description: Collect, levy, or bring together (money or resources)

examples: he was born and raised in San Francisco
God raised Jesus from the dead

verb.description: Abandon or force an enemy to abandon (a siege, blockade, or embargo).

examples: the jack rabbit was only 250 yards from where he first raised it

verb.description: (of someone at sea) come in sight of (land or another ship)
examples: they raised the low coast by evening

verb.description: Stimulate production of (an antiserum, antibody, or other biologically active substance) against the appropriate target cell or substance.

examples: he wants a raise and some perks

noun.description: (in poker or brag) an increase in a stake.
An act of lifting or raising a part of the body while holding a weight.

phrases: There are twenty-four tracks where she'll scream and shout and raise the devil.
I raised my glass to Susan
He glances at the portrait of Heinrich, and raises his glass.
Congratulations, he said, raising his glass.
We raise our glasses and sing victory songs to Paul.
origin: Middle English: from Old Norse reisa; related to the verb rear.
